abstract.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}abstract{/c} keyword marks a class or member as incomplete and meant to be inherited. Abstract members must be implemented by derived classes.

add.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}add{/c} keyword defines how a handler is attached to an event. It runs when code subscribes to the event.

alias.Definition: {c:color-blue keyword}alias{/c} creates an alternate name for a namespace or type to help simplify long or conflicting qualified names.

and.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}and{/c} keyword is used in pattern matching to require multiple conditions to be true. All parts of the pattern must match.

as.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}as{/c} keyword attempts to convert a value to a specified type. If the conversion fails, it returns null instead of throwing an error.

ascending.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}ascending{/c} keyword sorts query results from lowest to highest. It is commonly used in LINQ order-by expressions.

async.Definition: {c:color-blue keyword}async{/c} marks a method as asynchronous which allows the method to run without blocking while waiting for work to finish.

await.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}await{/c} keyword pauses execution until an asynchronous operation completes. It allows the program to continue doing other work while waiting.

base.Definition: {c:color-blue keyword}base{/c} refers to a base class from which the current class inherits and is used to access the base class members.

bool.Definition: {c:color-blue keyword}bool{/c} defines a Boolean type value which can hold either true or false.

by.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}by{/c} keyword specifies how data should be grouped or ordered in a query. It works with keywords like group and order.

byte.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}byte{/c} keyword defines a small numeric type that stores whole numbers from 0 to 255. It is often used for raw data and memory-efficient storage.

break.Definition: {c:color-purple keyword}break{/c} immediately exits a loop or switch statement. Execution continues with the next statement after the block.

case.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}case{/c} keyword defines a branch in a switch statement. It specifies what code runs when a value matches.

catch.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}catch{/c} keyword handles errors that occur in a try block. It allows a program to respond to exceptions safely.

char.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}char{/c} keyword defines a single character value. It is written using single quotes, such as 'A'.

checked.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}checked{/c} keyword enables overflow checking for numeric operations. It causes an error if a calculation exceeds the allowed range.

class.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}class{/c} keyword defines a class, which is a blueprint for creating objects. Classes group related data and behavior together.

const.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}const{/c} keyword defines a value that cannot be changed after it is set. Constant values are known at compile time.

continue.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}continue{/c} keyword skips the rest of the current loop iteration. Execution continues with the next iteration of the loop.

decimal.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}decimal{/c} keyword defines a high-precision numeric type. It is commonly used for financial and monetary calculations.

default.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}default{/c} keyword provides a fallback value or action when no other option matches. It is commonly used in switch statements and default expressions.

delegate.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}delegate{/c} keyword defines a type that represents a method reference. It allows methods to be passed and invoked indirectly.

descending.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}descending{/c} keyword sorts query results from highest to lowest. It is used in LINQ order-by expressions.

do.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}do{/c} keyword starts a loop that runs at least once. The loop continues while a condition remains true.

double.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}double{/c} keyword defines a floating-point numeric type. It is used for numbers with decimal values.

dynamic.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}dynamic{/c} keyword defers type checking until runtime. It allows flexible behavior but removes compile-time type safety.

else.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}else{/c} keyword defines code that runs when an if condition is false. It provides an alternative execution path.

enum.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}enum{/c} keyword defines a set of named constant values. It is used to represent a fixed list of options.

equals.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}equals{/c} keyword specifies a value comparison in pattern matching. It checks whether two values are equal.

event.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}event{/c} keyword defines a notification that other code can subscribe to. It allows objects to react when something happens.

explicit.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}explicit{/c} keyword defines a conversion that must be written by the programmer. It prevents accidental or unsafe type conversions.

false.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}false{/c} keyword represents a Boolean value that means something is not true. It is commonly used in conditions and logical expressions.

file.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}file{/c} keyword applies certain declarations to a single source file. It helps limit visibility and avoid name conflicts.

finally.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}finally{/c} keyword defines code that always runs after a try or catch block. It is commonly used for cleanup tasks.

fixed.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}fixed{/c} keyword prevents data from being moved by the garbage collector. It is used when working with pointers in unsafe code.

float.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}float{/c} keyword defines a floating-point numeric type. It is used for numbers with decimal values and less precision than double.

for.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}for{/c} keyword starts a loop that runs a set number of times. It is commonly used when the number of iterations is known.

foreach.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}foreach{/c} keyword loops through each item in a collection. It simplifies working with lists and arrays.

from.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}from{/c} keyword specifies the data source in a LINQ query. It defines where the query begins.

get.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}get{/c} keyword defines how a property’s value is retrieved. It runs when the property is read.

global.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}global{/c} keyword refers to the global namespace or scope. It helps avoid naming conflicts.

group.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}group{/c} keyword groups query results based on a key. It is used in LINQ queries to organize data.

goto.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}goto{/c} keyword jumps execution to a labeled statement. It is rarely used because it can make code harder to follow.

if.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}if{/c} keyword executes code only when it's condition is {c:bold}true{/c}.

implicit.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}implicit{/c} keyword defines a conversion that happens automatically. It allows safe type conversions without extra syntax.

in.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}in{/c} keyword is used to iterate over collections or specify input-only parameters. It indicates that values are read but not modified.

init.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}init{/c} keyword allows a property to be set only during object creation. It helps create immutable objects.

int.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}int{/c} keyword defines a whole number type. It is commonly used for counting and indexing.

interface.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}interface{/c} keyword defines a contract that classes must follow. It specifies what members a class must implement.

internal.Definition: {c:color-blue keyword}internal{/c} members are accessible from any code within the same assembly but not from other assemblies.

into.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}into{/c} keyword continues a query after a group or join operation. It allows further processing of query results.

is.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}is{/c} keyword checks whether a value matches a given type or pattern. It is commonly used in conditions.

join.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}join{/c} keyword combines data from two sources based on a related value. It is used in LINQ queries to match items.

let.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}let{/c} keyword stores the result of an expression in a temporary variable. It helps simplify complex queries.

lock.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}lock{/c} keyword prevents multiple threads from accessing the same code at the same time. It helps avoid data corruption.

long.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}long{/c} keyword defines a whole number type that can store very large values. It is larger than int.

managed.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}managed{/c} keyword specifies that code is managed by the runtime. It is used in advanced interoperability scenarios.

nameof.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}nameof{/c} keyword returns the name of a variable, type, or member as a string. It helps avoid hard-coded names.

namespace.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}namespace{/c} keyword groups related types into a named scope, helping organize code and prevent naming conflicts across large projects.

new.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}new{/c} keyword creates a new instance of a type. It allocates memory and initializes the object.

nint.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}nint{/c} keyword defines an integer whose size depends on the platform. It is commonly used in low-level or interop code.

not.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}not{/c} keyword negates a pattern or condition. It matches when the pattern does not apply.

notnull.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}notnull{/c} keyword constrains a generic type to non-null values. It ensures null is not allowed.

nuint.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}nuint{/c} keyword defines an unsigned integer whose size depends on the platform. It is used for low-level or interop scenarios.

null.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}null{/c} keyword represents the absence of a value or object reference. It means nothing is assigned.

object.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}object{/c} keyword represents the base type of all types in C#. Every type ultimately derives from object.

on.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}on{/c} keyword specifies the condition used to match items in a join query. It defines how data sources are related.

operator.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}operator{/c} keyword defines a custom operator for a type. It controls how operators like + or == behave.

or.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}or{/c} keyword is used in pattern matching to allow alternative matches. At least one condition must be true.

orderby.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}orderby{/c} keyword sorts query results. It is commonly used in LINQ expressions.

out.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}out{/c} keyword passes a variable by reference to a method. The method assigns the value before returning.

override.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}override{/c} keyword replaces a base class method with a new implementation. It allows derived classes to change behavior.

params.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}params{/c} keyword allows a method to accept a variable number of arguments. It simplifies passing multiple values.

partial.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}partial{/c} keyword splits a class, struct, or method across multiple files. It helps organize large codebases.

private.Definition: {c:color-blue keyword}private{/c} members are only accessible within the class or struct in which they are declared.

protected.Definition: {c:color-blue keyword}protected{/c} members are accessible within the containing class and by derived (child) classes.

public.Definition: {c:color-blue keyword}public{/c} members are accessible from any other code within the same assembly or another assembly that references it.

readonly.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}readonly{/c} keyword allows a field to be assigned only during initialization. It prevents modification after construction.

record.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}record{/c} keyword defines a data-focused type with value-based equality. It is commonly used for immutable data.

ref.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}ref{/c} keyword passes a variable by reference. Changes made inside the method affect the original value.

remove.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}remove{/c} keyword defines how a handler is detached from an event. It runs when code unsubscribes from the event.

required.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}required{/c} keyword enforces that a property must be set during object creation. It helps ensure objects are properly initialized.

return.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}return{/c} keyword sends a value back from a method and ends its execution. It defines the result of the method.

sbyte.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}sbyte{/c} keyword defines a small signed numeric type. It stores whole numbers from -128 to 127.

sealed.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}sealed{/c} keyword prevents a class from being inherited. It locks the class so it cannot be extended.

select.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}select{/c} keyword chooses which values are returned from a query. It defines the shape of the query result.

set.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}set{/c} keyword defines how a property’s value is assigned. It runs when a property is written to.

short.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}short{/c} keyword defines a small whole number type. It stores values from -32,768 to 32,767.

stackalloc.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}stackalloc{/c} keyword allocates memory on the stack instead of the heap. It is used for high-performance or low-level scenarios.

static.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}static{/c} keyword defines members that belong to a type rather than an instance. Static members are shared across all objects.

string.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}string{/c} keyword defines a sequence of characters. It is commonly used to represent text.

struct.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}struct{/c} keyword defines a value type that groups related data together. Structs are often used for small, lightweight objects.

switch.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}switch{/c} keyword selects which code to run based on a value or pattern. It provides a clear alternative to multiple if statements.

this.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}this{/c} keyword refers to the current instance of a class or struct. It is used to access instance members.

throw.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}throw{/c} keyword raises an exception. It signals that an error has occurred.

true.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}true{/c} keyword represents a Boolean value that means something is correct or enabled. It is used in logical expressions.

try.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}try{/c} keyword wraps code that might cause an error. It works with catch and finally to handle exceptions.

uint.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}uint{/c} keyword defines an unsigned whole number type. It stores values from 0 to 4,294,967,295.

ulong.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}ulong{/c} keyword defines a very large unsigned whole number type. It is used when extremely large values are needed.

unmanaged.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}unmanaged{/c} keyword restricts a generic type to unmanaged types. It ensures the type does not contain managed references.

ushort.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}ushort{/c} keyword defines a small unsigned whole number type. It stores values from 0 to 65,535.

unchecked.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}unchecked{/c} keyword disables overflow checking for numeric operations. It allows calculations to wrap without errors.

unsafe.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}unsafe{/c} keyword allows code to use pointers and direct memory access. It bypasses some safety checks.

using.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}using{/c} keyword imports namespaces into the file so you can reference their types without fully qualifying their names.

value.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}value{/c} keyword represents the value being assigned to a property or indexer. It is implicitly provided by C# whenever the {c:color-blue keyword}set{/c}, {c:color-blue keyword}init{/c}, {c:color-blue keyword}add{/c}, or {c:color-blue keyword}remove{/c} accessors are invoked.

var.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}var{/c} keyword lets the compiler infer the type of a variable from its assigned value. The variable still has a strong, fixed type.

virtual.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}virtual{/c} keyword allows a method or property to be overridden in a derived class. It supports customizable behavior through inheritance.

void.Definition: The return type {c:color-blue keyword}void{/c} means the method does not return anything. The point of execution will return to where the method was called from but no data will be returned with it.

volatile.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}volatile{/c} keyword ensures a field is always read from and written to main memory. It helps prevent issues in multi-threaded code.

when.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}when{/c} keyword adds a condition to a catch block or pattern match. It controls when the code should run.

where.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}where{/c} keyword filters data in a query or applies constraints to generic types. It limits which values or types are allowed.

while.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}while{/c} keyword starts a loop that runs as long as a condition is true. The condition is checked before each iteration.

with.Definition: The {c:color-blue keyword}with{/c} keyword creates a copy of an object with selected values changed. It is commonly used with records.

yield.Definition: The {c:color-purple keyword}yield{/c} keyword returns values one at a time from a method. It allows lazy iteration over a sequence.
